soc.message

Class SOCMessage

  • java.lang.Object
    • soc.message.SOCMessage
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Cloneable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    SOCAcceptOffer, SOCAdminPing, SOCAdminReset, SOCAuthRequest, SOCBankTrade, SOCBCastTextMsg, SOCBoardLayout, SOCBoardLayout2, SOCBotJoinGameRequest, SOCBuildRequest, SOCBuyDevCardRequest, SOCCancelBuildRequest, SOCChangeFace, SOCChannelMembers, SOCChannels, SOCChannelTextMsg, SOCChoosePlayer, SOCChoosePlayerRequest, SOCClearOffer, SOCClearTradeMsg, SOCCreateAccount, SOCDebugFreePlace, SOCDeleteChannel, SOCDeleteGame, SOCDevCardAction, SOCDevCardCount, SOCDiscard, SOCDiscardRequest, SOCDisconnect, SOCEndTurn, SOCFirstPlayer, SOCGameMembers, SOCGameOptionGetDefaults, SOCGameOptionGetInfos, SOCGames, SOCGameServerText, SOCGameState, SOCGameStats, SOCGameTextMsg, SOCImARobot, SOCInventoryItemAction, SOCJoinChannel, SOCJoinChannelAuth, SOCJoinGameAuth, SOCLargestArmy, SOCLastSettlement, SOCLeaveAll, SOCLeaveChannel, SOCLeaveGame, SOCLongestRoad, SOCMakeOffer, SOCMessageMulti, SOCMessageTemplate0, SOCMessageTemplate1i, SOCMessageTemplate1s, SOCMessageTemplate2i, SOCMessageTemplate2s, SOCMessageTemplate3i, SOCMessageTemplate3s, SOCMessageTemplate4i, SOCMessageTemplateJoinGame, SOCMoveRobber, SOCNewChannel, SOCNewGame, SOCPickResources, SOCPickResourceType, SOCPlayDevCardRequest, SOCPlayerElement, SOCPotentialSettlements, SOCPutPiece, SOCRejectConnection, SOCRejectOffer, SOCReportRobbery, SOCResourceCount, SOCRobotDismiss, SOCRollDice, SOCRollDicePrompt, SOCServerPing, SOCSetPlayedDevCard, SOCSetSeatLock, SOCSetSpecialItem, SOCSitDown, SOCStartGame, SOCStatusMessage, SOCSVPTextMessage, SOCTimingPing, SOCTurn, SOCUpdateRobotParams, SOCVersion

    public abstract class SOCMessage
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Cloneable
    Messages used for game data, events, and chatting on a channel.

    Text announcements (SOCGameServerText or SOCGameTextMsg) are often sent after data messages. Bots ignore text messages except for a few bot-debug commands.

    Implementation:

    No Objects, only strings and integers, are to be sent over the network between servers and clients! Your game's code must guarantee that no string sent contains a separator character (sep_char or sep2_char). To help with this, use isSingleLineAndSafe(String). Keeping the network protocol simple helps with interoperability between different versions and implementations.

    The message data is sent over the network as type ID + data strings built by each SOCMessage subclass's toCmd() method. This is sent over TCP using DataOutputStream.writeUTF(String). Server-launched local AI bots use MemConnection instead of TCP, and skip the UTF encoding/decoding overhead.

    On the remote end, a message is reconstructed to a new instance of the appropriate SOCMessage subclass, by the subclass' required method static SOCMessageSubclass parseDataStr(String). parseDataStr is called from toMsg(String) in this class. Remote TCP clients receive data using DataInputStream.readUTF().

    The client receives messages in MessageHandler.handle(SOCMessage, Connection). The server receives messages in SOCServerMessageDispatcher.dispatch(SOCMessage, Connection).

    Human-readable format:

    For debugging purposes, toString() should include all fields sent over the network in a human-readable form. That's also a useful format if messages are being written to a log that someone might want to read and interpret later. For documentation, we recommend including the current Version.versionNumber() or a SOCVersion message near the start of such a log.

    Starting in v2.4.50, the toString() form must be parsable back into SOCMessage through parseMsgStr(String). This "round-trip" parsing is useful for third-party projects which wrote human-readable message logs and want to interpret or replay them later. See that method's javadoc for details.

    To create and add a new message type:

    • Decide on the message type name. Make sure the new name has never been used (check MESSAGE_RENAME_MAP). Add to the end of the constant list in this class. Add a comment to note the JSettlers version in which it was introduced, and the date.
    • If the new message is for something that any kind of game can use, give it the next available type ID number in the list (1xxx). If the message is specific to the JSettlers game and its interface, use a message number above 10000. The intention is that other kinds of games can be played eventually within this server framework. For message types added during a fork or third-party work, use the 2xxx range; that range won't be used by the JSettlers core itself.
    • Add it to the switch in toMsg(String). Again, note the version with a comment. In the switch you will call yourMessageType.parseDataStr(data). If your message class extends SOCMessageTemplateMs or SOCMessageTemplateMi, instead call yourMessageType.parseDataStr(multiData): for details see SOCMessageMulti class javadoc.
    • If the message contains a game name, your new class must implement SOCMessageForGame.
    • If the message can be sent to server from clients which haven't yet authenticated, must implement marker SOCMessageFromUnauthClient.
    • Extend the SOCMessage class or a template class, including the required parseDataStr method. (SOCRevealFogHex and SOCSetTurn are good example subclasses.) Template parent-classes can help; the example subclasses extend them. Be sure to override the minimum version reported in getMinimumVersion(). Set serialVersionUID to the version it's added in. for example, if adding for version 1.1.09: private static final long serialVersionUID = 1109L;
    • Add to the switch in SOCPlayerClient.treat and/or SOCServerMessageHandler.dispatch or its game type's GameMessageHandler.dispatch. Note the JSettlers version with a comment.

      Note: Most things added to SOCPlayerClient.treat should also be added to SOCMessageDispatcher.dispatch(SOCMessage, Connection) . If robots should react, also add to SOCRobotClient.dispatch(SOCMessage, Connection) and maybe also SOCRobotBrain.run().

      If the message is player-state related, you might also want to add it in your game type's soc.server.GameHandler.sitDown_sendPrivateInfo().

    • If the toString() form has fields that can't be automatically parsed by parseMsgStr(String), such as hex values or int constant strings, write a stripAttribNames(..) method to help: See parseMsgStr(..) javadocs for details.
    • Add it to unit test soctest.message.TestToCmdToStringParse's TOCMD_TOSTRING_COMPARES array

    Backwards compatibility:

    Unknown message types are ignored by client and by server: They are returned as null from toMsg(String) if the local copy (the old version's code) of SOCMessage doesn't know that message type.

    Changing or adding to a message type:

    It's sometimes useful to add new fields to a message, to support new features or optimize the message stream.

    It's important that previous JSettlers versions are still able to parse the message when it includes its new field(s), unless the addition supports a feature which isn't compatible with those previous versions. Try to avoid adding code to the server/client to send different formats of the same message to different versions. Compatibility is made easier because most messages' parseDataStr methods will ignore extra fields and/or were designed to be extensible by using field markers, length prefixes, etc.

    Renaming a message or improving its toString() form:

    For debugging purposes, it's sometimes useful to make the output of toString() more meaningful: Translating enum integers like pieceType to their strings, etc.

    In versions after 2.4.50: If you must make an incompatible change to a message's toString form, and a previous version's parseMsgStr(String) wouldn't be able to parse that new form, rename the message class and make sure the old name can still be parsed with its old format (see MESSAGE_RENAME_MAP, write a static stripAttribNames(messageTypeName, messageStrParams), etc.) Don't change the message getType() constant's numeric value.

    Format:

    For most messages, at most one sep token per message, which separates its getType() number from the message data; multiple SEP2 are allowed after SEP. For multi-messages, multiple SEP are allowed; see SOCMessageMulti. Some message types allow blank fields; these must use a token like EMPTYSTR to avoid adjacent field separators.
    Author:
    Robert S Thomas
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

      To identify new message types, give the minimum version where this type is used.
      int getType() 
      static boolean isSingleLineAndSafe(java.lang.String s)
      Test whether a string is non-empty and its characters are all 'safe' as a single-line string: No newlines or control characters, no line separators or paragraph separators.
      static boolean isSingleLineAndSafe(java.lang.String s, boolean allowSepChars)
      Variant of isSingleLineAndSafe(String) that can optionally allow sep_char or sep2_char.
      static SOCMessage parseMsgStr(java.lang.String messageStr)
      Parse a delimited message in toString() format: SOCPutPiece:game=test5|playerNumber=3|pieceType=0|coord=40a
      Strips parameter/attribute names from values to get the format expected by message types' parseDataStr(..), calls that.
      void setDebugTraffic(boolean debugTraffic) 
      static java.lang.String stripAttribNames(java.lang.String messageStrParams)
      Strip out the parameter/attribute names from toString()'s format, returning message parameters as a comma-delimited list for parseMsgStr(String) to pass to the message class's parseDataStr(String).
      static java.util.List<java.lang.String> stripAttribsToList(java.lang.String messageStrParams)
      Strip out the parameter/attribute names from toString()'s format, returning message parameters as a list for further parsing or for parseMsgStr(String) to pass to a SOCMessageMulti message class's parseDataStr(List).
      abstract java.lang.String toCmd()
      Converts the contents of this message into a String that can be transferred by a client or server.
      static SOCMessage toMsg(java.lang.String s)
      Convert a string from toCmd() into a SOCMessage.
      abstract java.lang.String toString()
      Simple human-readable delimited representation, used for debug purposes: SOCPutPiece:game=test5|playerNumber=3|pieceType=0|coord=40a
      Could also be used by a SOCServer.recordGameEvent(String, SOCMessage) implementation.

    • Field Detail

      • EMPTYSTR

        public static final java.lang.String EMPTYSTR
        Placeholder token to represent a null or empty string over the network to avoid 2 adjacent field-delimiter characters, used in some message types: A single tab "\t".

        If using this token for a new message type's field(s), be sure the token could never be a valid value for the field. To help with this, the token value fails isSingleLineAndSafe(String).

        Since:
        2.0.00
        See Also:
        GAME_NONE, SOCMessageTemplateMs.parseData_FindEmptyStrs(java.util.List), Constant Field Values

        public static final int NULLMESSAGE
        Null message type; toMsg(String) returns null for this type. There is no constructor for this message type: For a trivial message see SOCServerPing instead.

      • sep

        public static final java.lang.String sep
        Token separators. At most one SEP per message; multiple SEP2 are allowed after SEP. For multi-messages, multiple SEP are allowed; see SOCMessageMulti. SEP is "|".
        See Also:
        sep_char, sepRE, Constant Field Values

      • sepRE

        public static final java.lang.String sepRE
        Main SEP separator, in regexp form for splits and replacements.
        Since:
        2.4.50
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • sep2

        public static final java.lang.String sep2
        Secondary separator token SEP2, as string. SEP2 is ",".
        See Also:
        sep2_char, Constant Field Values

        public static final char sep_char
        Main separator token sep, as character. SEP is '|'.
        Since:
        1.1.00

        Constant Field Values

        public static final char sep2_char
        Secondary separator token sep2, as character. SEP2 is ','.
        Since:
        1.1.00
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • GAME_NONE

        public static final java.lang.String GAME_NONE
        "Not for any game" marker, used when any of the SOCMessageTemplate* message types (which all implement SOCMessageForGame) are used for convenience for non-game messages such as SOCLocalizedStrings.

        No actual game, option, or scenario will ever have the same name as this marker, because the marker fails isSingleLineAndSafe(String, false): Marker is control character ^V (SYN): (char) 22.

        Since:
        2.0.00
        See Also:
        EMPTYSTR, Constant Field Values

      • messageType

        protected int messageType
        An ID identifying the type of message; see getType().

      • MESSAGE_RENAME_MAP

        public static java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> MESSAGE_RENAME_MAP
        Map of renamed classes for backwards compatibility in parseMsgStr(String): Key is old name of message type, value is new name (SOCMessage subclass). See parseMsgStr(..) javadoc for more details, including expected static stripAttribNames(messageTypeName, messageStrParams) method.
        Since:
        2.4.50

      • getType

        public int getType()
        Returns:
        the message type number sent over the network, such as JOINGAMEAUTH or PUTPIECE

      • getMinimumVersion

        public int getMinimumVersion()
        To identify new message types, give the minimum version where this type is used. Default of 1000 (version 1.0.00) unless overridden.

        When overriding, write the entire method on a single line for easier visibility of the version when searching the source code.

        Returns:
        Version number, as in 1006 for JSettlers 1.0.06.
        Since:
        1.1.00

      • getMaximumVersion

        public int getMaximumVersion()
        To identify obsolete message types, give the maximum version where this type is used. Default (for active messages) returns Integer.MAX_VALUE.
        Returns:
        Version number, as in 1006 for JSettlers 1.0.06, or Integer.MAX_VALUE.
        Since:
        1.1.00

      • toCmd

        public abstract java.lang.String toCmd()
        Converts the contents of this message into a String that can be transferred by a client or server. For a human-readable alternative, see toString().

        Your message class's required method static SOCMessageSubclass parseDataStr(String) must be able to turn this String back into an instance of the message class.

        For most message types, at most one sep token is allowed, separating the type ID from the rest of the parameters. For multi-messages (@link SOCMessageMulti}, multiple sep tokens are allowed. Multi-messages are parsed with: static SOCMessageSubclass parseDataStr(String[])

        Overall conversion from toCmd() format is handled by toMsg(String), which checks message type ID to call the appropriate class's parseDataStr.

      • toString

        public abstract java.lang.String toString()
        Simple human-readable delimited representation, used for debug purposes: SOCPutPiece:game=test5|playerNumber=3|pieceType=0|coord=40a
        Could also be used by a SOCServer.recordGameEvent(String, SOCMessage) implementation.

        Within this representation, message parameters should be in same order used by toCmd() and parseDataStr(..). Should be parseable by parseMsgStr(String) which calls stripAttribNames(String), which your class can override if needed.

        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object
        Since:
        1.1.00
        See Also:
        toCmd()

      • isSingleLineAndSafe

        public static boolean isSingleLineAndSafe(java.lang.String s)
        Test whether a string is non-empty and its characters are all 'safe' as a single-line string: No newlines or control characters, no line separators or paragraph separators. Whitespace character type Character.SPACE_SEPARATOR is OK. Must not contain sep_char or sep2_char.
        Parameters:
        s - string to test; if null or "", returns false.
        Returns:
        true if all characters are OK, false otherwise. Null string or 0-length string returns false.
        Since:
        1.1.07
        See Also:
        isSingleLineAndSafe(String, boolean)

      • isSingleLineAndSafe

        public static boolean isSingleLineAndSafe(java.lang.String s,
                                          boolean allowSepChars)
        Variant of isSingleLineAndSafe(String) that can optionally allow sep_char or sep2_char. See that method for other conditions checked here.
        Parameters:
        s - string to test; if null or "", returns false.
        allowSepChars - If true, string can contain sep_char or sep2_char
        Returns:
        true if all characters are OK, false otherwise. Null string or 0-length string returns false.
        Since:
        2.0.00

      • toMsg

        public static SOCMessage toMsg(java.lang.String s)
        Convert a string from toCmd() into a SOCMessage. The string is in the form of "id SEP messagename { SEP2 messagedata }*". If the message type id is unknown, that is printed to System.err. Otherwise calls message type's static parseDataStr method.
        Parameters:
        s - String to convert
        Returns:
        converted String to a SOCMessage, or null if the string is garbled, or is an unknown command id

      • parseMsgStr

        public static SOCMessage parseMsgStr(java.lang.String messageStr)
                              throws java.text.ParseException,
                                     java.util.InputMismatchException
        Parse a delimited message in toString() format: SOCPutPiece:game=test5|playerNumber=3|pieceType=0|coord=40a
        Strips parameter/attribute names from values to get the format expected by message types' parseDataStr(..), calls that.

        If toString() format has fields that can't be automatically parsed here, such as hex values or int constant strings, message class should have a static stripAttribNames(String) method to do so. See SOCPutPiece.stripAttribNames(String) and SOCVersion.stripAttribNames(String) for simple examples.

        Message types which have been renamed and noted in MESSAGE_RENAME_MAP, and the old name used an incompatibly different toString format, should declare a static stripAttribNames(String messageTypeName, String messageStrParams) method to know whether to parse using the old or new format.

        Uses reflection to call the message type's static stripAttribNames(String) and parseDataStr(String or List<String>) methods if available, otherwise stripAttribNames(String).

        Parameters:
        messageStr - Message as delimited string from toString(); not null
        Returns:
        parsed message if successful, throws exception otherwise
        Throws:
        java.util.InputMismatchException - if message can't be parsed and parseMsgStr(String) returned null
        java.text.ParseException - if message class name not parsed or class not found, reflection error (method not static, etc), or if message's stripAttribNames(String) or parseMsgStr(String) threw an exception
        Since:
        2.4.50

      • stripAttribNames

        public static java.lang.String stripAttribNames(java.lang.String messageStrParams)
        Strip out the parameter/attribute names from toString()'s format, returning message parameters as a comma-delimited list for parseMsgStr(String) to pass to the message class's parseDataStr(String).

        Some messages will need to override this (new game with options, any of the types which use hex encoding of coordinates). Message types which have been renamed, and the old name used an incompatibly different toString format, should instead declare a static stripAttribNames(String messageTypeName, String messageStrParams) method: See parseMsgStr(String) javadoc.

        For SOCMessageMulti subclasses, use or override stripAttribsToList(String) instead.

        Parameters:
        messageStrParams - Params part of a message string formatted by toString(); not null
        Returns:
        Message parameters without attribute names, or null if params are malformed. If messageStrParams is "", returns "".
        Since:
        2.4.50
        See Also:
        stripAttribsToList(String)

      • stripAttribsToList

        public static java.util.List<java.lang.String> stripAttribsToList(java.lang.String messageStrParams)
        Strip out the parameter/attribute names from toString()'s format, returning message parameters as a list for further parsing or for parseMsgStr(String) to pass to a SOCMessageMulti message class's parseDataStr(List).
        Parameters:
        messageStrParams - Params part of a message string formatted by toString(); not null
        Returns:
        Message parameters to finish parsing into a SOCMessage, or null if malformed. If messageStrParams is "", returns a list with "" as its sole element. The returned List might not support optional methods like List.add(int, Object).
        Since:
        2.4.50
        See Also:
        stripAttribNames(String)
